abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency Repatriation
            and Livelihood Restoration of Migrant Workers Project for
            Bangladesh were as follows: overall outcome was highly
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was low or
            negligible, and the Bank and the borrower performance were
            satisfactory. There were some important project lessons
            learned. (1) Fast track emergency operations for migration
            are feasible. (2) The Bank can be responsive to borrower
            needs in emergencies, but this requires flexibility in the
            application of Bank rules. (3) Simplicity of project design
            facilitates implementation in emergency operations and
            provides a greater opportunity for achieving project design.
            (4) Planning for the unplanned is important because
            emergencies are dynamic and identification of additional
            needs may not be possible. (5) Emergency operations cannot
            wait for rigorous analytic work to inform design; however,
            to the degree possible, the Bank needs to take stock of the
            situation. (6) Development of operational manuals prior to
            the first disbursement of a cash transfer is good practice
            and feasible in emergency situations. (7) Third-party
            processes audits could be important accountability and
            control mechanisms. (8) Emergencies provide opportunities to
            build systems to reduce the impact of future shocks. (9)
            Emergency operations should endeavor to include support for
            capacity building and knowledge generation. (10) If designed
            well, it is possible to achieve high returns without
            incurring large administrative costs. (11) Conversion of
            local currency into home country currency for migrants is a
            good practice which should be included in future
            repatriation operations.
